content:
‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I like the puzzle

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: this is a good puzzle :)

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Fun challenge, all three modes can perfectly apply.
The presentation is clear, and I don't remember any challenge like this.

Goal
* Please mention that any characters outside the range need not be counted and can be ignored.

* Please format "No" and "Nothing to process" as {{constants}}.

* Please change "If the ASCII difference between the first and last characters is less than 1" to "If the ASCII value of the first character is <<not smaller>> than the ASCII value of the last character".

Input
* Please add "[[input]]" after "A string".

Output
* It isn't necessary to repeat everything here. Please rewrite as follows:

<<Several lines>>: The frequencies of all the characters within the required range, or
<<1 line>>: {{Nothing to process}}.

Constraints
* Please change "[[ASCII Value]]" to "ASCII value of each character in [[input]]".

* Please change "[[Input str length]]" to "length of [[input]]".

* Please change 10100 to 2000.

* Please delete the last constraint as it does not hold in some cases.

Cases
(Below changes are for the purpose of better coverage and more similar tests and validators.)

* Easy Validator: Please change the case to cover uppercase letters only.

* 0-frequency test: Please change the case to cover special characters only.

* Invalid Range Validator: Please change the case so that the input string contains 2 characters.

* Final Validator: Please change "‚Äî" (ASCII value = 8212) to "-" (ASCII value = 45) (3 times).

* Please add a pair of cases where the input string contains a single character only.

* Please add a pair of cases where the length of [[input]] is greater than 2 and the first character is larger than the last character in ASCII value.

* Please add a pair of cases where the first character is a lowercase letter, and some of the characters in the middle are uppercase letters.

* Please add a pair of cases where the first character is a digit, and some of the characters in the middle are mathematical operators.

* Please add a pair of cases where the first character is a mathematical operator, and some of the characters in the middle are digits.

* Please add a pair of cases where the first character is { or | or }, and some of the characters in the middle are English letters.

Thanks.

Wow, thanks for taking the time to dissect my mumble jumble and make sense of it. I am very grateful.

I took everything you wrote into account and implemented it, although now I think I have too many tests.
Thank you for the feedback! I wasn't sure about reverse mode, as explaining the assignment in words was difficult. Your approval means a lot ‚Äî thanks again.

Thank you for following up! üëçüèª

I think the default number of case pairs (4) is often too low, allowing some code to pass all author-created tests and validators while still failing in other scenarios. Increasing this to 7 to 10 pairs strikes a good balance: not too many, but enough to enhance testing vigour, provide more cases for players to test out their code, and offer additional hints in a Reverse mode CoC.

May I suggest one small change in the cases? In
‚Ä¢ Math (test) and
‚Ä¢ Math Validator,
change the output to "Nothing to process", and also change the input accordingly (e.g. 10 * 2 * 3 = 60). The purpose is to cover the scenario of a longer string with "Nothing to process", which is not currently covered in any cases.

Thanks again.
Done! I am quite satisfied with the outcome. Thanks to you my tests are looking pretty good.
